html: @jonas thanks but I'm simply following in the rather large footsteps of others. The pure JS implementation of git was done by Ryan Ackley, I just built on top of his lib to add submodules, reading the dircache, detached heads, etc. I basically really missed having tig on my Chromebook and its the last missing piece as there are already some nice editors as packaged apps (work offline) even an embedded mcu IDE, serial terminal etc. Plan is to bring across more of tig's features as I have time to work on it. It would be nice if I could just port tig across using emscripten but I think I'm too far down the road now with the JS port of git.

text: hey guys, trying to tinker with tig; haven't touched C for about 10 years now and am trying to grok the project: how would I go about adding a new command?  I can see global constants for commands, but can't find where they are defined.

html: @rapilabs Hi, depends what type of command you want to add. Shell commands (also known as user-defined actions) can be defined in tigrc. If you are talking about new internal actions the enum request is defined in include/tig/request.h and implemented in the *_request methods of the different views (e.g. src/diff.c).
text: @rapilabs Hi, depends what type of command you want to add. Shell commands (also known as user-defined actions) can be defined in `tigrc`. If you are talking about new internal actions the `enum request` is defined in `include/tig/request.h` and implemented in the `*_request` methods of the different views (e.g. `src/diff.c`).

html: @schnittchen Use X to toggle id display on/off. Else you can add set main-view-id-display = yes to your ~/.tigrc to always show IDs in the main view (replace main with blame etc. to enable this for other views).

html:
Hi @jonas, I'm using a few global git aliases that might be interesting:

[alias]
        tig = "!f () { git \"$@\" --pretty=raw | tig --pretty=raw ; }; f"
        tog = "!git tig log"
        reftog = "!git tig reflog"

So you can git reftog or git tog --author=jonas --since=19feb for instance.

If someone's interesting in putting that in the wiki...
text:
Hi @jonas, I'm using a few global git aliases that might be interesting:

````
[alias]
        tig = "!f () { git \"$@\" --pretty=raw | tig --pretty=raw ; }; f"
        tog = "!git tig log"
        reftog = "!git tig reflog"
````

So you can `git reftog` or `git tog --author=jonas --since=19feb` for instance.

See INSTALL.adoc:

Installation on Windows
-----------------------
To run on Windows, you will need [cygwin](https://www.cygwin.com/).
You must then install the packages `git`, `gcc-core`, `make`, `libiconv-devel`
and `libncurses-devel`. Extract the tarball and install by using `configure`
as explained above.

html: Try set diff-options = --stat-name-width=123
text: Try `set diff-options = --stat-name-width=123`

html:
--stat[=<width>[,<name-width>[,<count>]]]
      Generate a diffstat. By default, as much space as necessary will be used for the filename part, and the rest for the graph part. Maximum width defaults to terminal width, or 80 columns if not connected to a terminal, and can be overridden by <width>. The width of the filename part can be limited by giving another width <name-width> after a comma. The width of the graph part can be limited by using --stat-graph-width=<width> (affects all commands generating a stat graph) or by setting diff.statGraphWidth=<width> (does not affect git format-patch). By giving a third parameter <count>, you can limit the output to the first <count> lines, followed by ...  if there are more.

      These parameters can also be set individually with --stat-width=<width>, --stat-name-width=<name-width> and --stat-count=<count>.

html:
that's acceptable. so in the end myrepo.git/config looks like this:
[core]
    repositoryformatversion = 0
    filemode = true
    bare = true
    worktree = /home/igor
[status]
    showUntrackedFiles = no
[tig]
    status-untracked-dirs = false
text:

	showUntrackedFiles = no

On event: whole file staged {
  if (diff-view is open) {

      show file below in diff-view
    } else if (status-view has file above) {
      select file above in status-view
      show file above in diff-view
    } else {
      // must be no files left in status view
      close diff-view
    }
  }
}

Hi folks, I'm tearing my hair out trying to understand tig config format; I've spent over an hour on this but it seems like it should be so simple.
I would like to set main-view = id date:default author:width:3 commit-title:yes,graph,refs, with the local date, but set main-view-date-local = true doesn't make that happen unless I don't set main-view at all. How can I get what I want?
text:
Hi folks, I'm tearing my hair out trying to understand tig config format; I've spent over an hour on this but it seems like it should be so simple.
I would like to `set main-view  = id date:default author:width:3 commit-title:yes,graph,refs`, with the *local* date, but `set main-view-date-local = true` doesn't make that happen unless I don't `set main-view` at all. How can I get what I want?

html: Oh, for crying out loud. The ordering of those lines is important. main-view before main-vew-date-local works, but that's not what I was doing. Well that answers my question (unless there's a better way to do this)
text: Oh, for crying out loud. The ordering of those lines is important. `main-view` *before* `main-vew-date-local` works, but that's not what I was doing. Well that answers my question (unless there's a better way to do this)

html:
They could be combined into one line
set main-view = id date:default,local author:width:3 commit-title:yes,graph,refs
text:
They could be combined into one line
```text
set main-view = id date:default,local author:width:3 commit-title:yes,graph,refs
```

html:
I got it working, the actual variable name is not the one displayed in tig when toogling the option. See "View settings" section in the documentation https://jonas.github.io/tig/doc/tigrc.5.html

In the end my file looks like this:
set main-view-date = relative-compact
set main-view-author = abbreviated
set main-view-commit-title-overflow = 50
set line-graphics = utf-8

@jonas Using tig 2.2: I have a .gitattributes file with

*.crypt.* filter=git-crypt diff=git-crypt
.gitattributes !filter !diff

.git/config contains

[filter "git-crypt"]
    smudge = \"git-crypt\" smudge
    clean = \"git-crypt\" clean
    required = true
[diff "git-crypt"]
    textconv = \"git-crypt\" diff

git diff uses the filter and/or diff from .gitattributes, but tig does not use it when viewing an unstaged diff, is this a bug or a missing feature?
text:
@jonas Using tig 2.2: I have a .gitattributes file with
```
*.crypt.* filter=git-crypt diff=git-crypt
.gitattributes !filter !diff
```
.git/config contains
```
[filter "git-crypt"]
	smudge = \"git-crypt\" smudge
	clean = \"git-crypt\" clean
	required = true
[diff "git-crypt"]
	textconv = \"git-crypt\" diff
```
`git diff` uses the filter and/or diff from `.gitattributes`, but `tig` does not use it when viewing an unstaged diff, is this a bug or a missing feature?

html: @joar Tig is quite old-school when it comes to the status and stage views. It uses git diff-index, which probably doesn't honor .gitattributes.

html: @collinpeters The default keybindings wire C in the main view, so you need to also add bind main C !git commit -v.
